head.title: Classification of plethories in characteristic zero
head.abstract: We classify plethories over fields of characteristic zero, thus answering a question of Borger-Wieland and Bergman. All plethories over characteristic zero fields are linear, in the sense that they are free plethories on a bialgebra. For the proof we need some facts from the theory of ring schemes where we extend previously known results. We also classify plethories with trivial Verschiebung over a perfect field of non-zero characteristic and indicate future work.

outline._note: Plethories, first introduced by Tall-Wraith , and then studied by Borger-Wieland , are precisely the objects which act on -algebras, for a commutative ring. There are many fundamental questions regarding plethories which remain unanswered. One such question is, given a ring whether one can classify plethories over in this paper we will take a first step towards a classification.\ For some motivation, let us start by looking at the category of modules over a commutative ring If we consider the category of representable functors there is a monoidal structure given by composition of functors. Then one defines a -algebra as a -module together with a comonad structure on the representable endofunctor with respect to composition of functors. Heuristically, this says that a -algebra is precisely the kind of object which knows how to act on -modules. This can be extended to a non-linear setting, so that instead of looking at -modules we look at -algebras and consider representable endofunctors A comonoid with respect to composition of functors is then called a plethory and analogously, a plethory is what knows how to act on -algebras. One particular important example of a plethory is the -algebra which consist of the ring of symmetric functions in infinitely many variables with a certain biring structure. The functor represents the functor taking a ring to its ring of Witt vectors. Using plethories one gets a very conceptual view of Witt vectors and in James Borger develops the geometry of Witt vectors using the plethystic perspective.\ Let now be a field. If we let denote the category of plethories over there is a forgetful functor into the category of cocommutative counital bialgebras over This functor has a left adjoint and we say that a plethory is linear if for some cocommutative, counital bialgebra Heuristically, a plethory is linear if every action of on an algebra comes from an action of a bialgebra on The main theorem of this paper is: Let be a field of characteristic zero. Then any -plethory is linear. This answers a question of Bergman-Hausknecht and Borger-Wieland in the positive. The theorem is proved by studying the category of affine ring schemes. We have the following results, extending those of Greenberg to arbitrary fields and not necesarily reduced schemes: Let be a field. Then any connected ring scheme of finite type is unipotent. Let be a connected ring scheme of finite type over Then is affine. For the case of characteristic our classification results on plethories are not as complete and further work is needed to have a complete classification. To explain our classification results here we need some definitions. Let be the Frobenius homomorphism of and be the non-commutative ring which as underlying set is and has multiplication given by and We define to be the category of cocommutative, counital bialgebras over which also are modules over Once again, for a plethory over a perfect field of char there is a forgetful functor which has a left adjoint Call a plethory -linear if for some We have then the following classification result: Let be a perfect field of characteristic Assume that is a plethory over such that the Verschiebung Then is -linear. The structure of this paper is as follows. In section we study ring schemes and prove some results which we will need for our classification theorem. The main theorems of this section that are needed for later purposes are Theorem and Theorem . In section we introduce plethories and -birings and provide some examples. This section contains no new results and gives just a brief introduction to the relevant objects as defined in Borger-Wieland . In section we prove that all plethories over a field of characteristic zero is linear using the results from section We also show that any -biring is connected. In section we prove some initial classification results regarding plethories in characteristic

We state future research directions, as well as give some ”pathological” examples which a complete classification must take into account.
